messageBody:
Hi,
 
As the name "unit testing" suggests, your best bet is to test each of your components one by one, in isolation.  But as you say, that can be tricky when the input to your component needs to come from some other component.  In these cases you may find it worthwhile to invest the time to create test stubs for these objects.
 
Here's an elementary example:  Suppose you're testing the "foo" method of your "Comp" component.  However, this method requires a "Bar" object to be passed in, and the only way to get one of these is to interact with some other component(s)--something of a unit-testing "no-no."
 
    public interface Comp {
        public void foo(Bar bar);
    }
 
What you want to do is create another implementation of the Bar interface called TestBar, which returns dummy test data instead of doing actual work.  (If Bar is not already an interface, renaming it something like BarImpl and making Bar an interface!)  Then create an instance of this TestBar object to test your foo() method with.
 
Does this help, or is it too elementary?
 
Kevin

From: Egger, Wolfgang [mailto:beuys@...]

To: 'junit@egroups.com'
Subject: [junit] testing distributed components

Servus,

we are developing a software-system, that consists of several components
that interact with serialized objects.
I'm wondering how to UnitTest such a system. It seems to be difficult,
becaus the output of one component is the input of another component. All
this components reside on different VMs and/or different hosts.

Has anyone tested such a system and can give any hints?

Thanx in advance

    Wolfgang
